audio_caption: The clip begins with a female speaker telling a story about Donald Trump and Joan Rivers on "Celebrity Apprentice," focusing on Trump paying for new implants and wanting her to replace Miss California. The speaker's tone is conversational and humorous. There is a shift to a musical interlude, likely pop or dance music, which evokes an upbeat, celebratory mood, possibly accompanying an introduction. Background sounds suggest a live audience cheering loudly with overlapping voices.

The audio clip begins with a burst of excited crowd noises, including whoops, cheering, and applause. This is followed by a female speaker beginning a sentence, then yelling "Ah!", possibly startled, while the crowd noise fades slightly. Another woman laughs and speaks, "That's what happens when you know too many people". A male voice briefly says "Hey John". The first female speaker speaks again, sounding playful, "Hello everyone. Love my darling. you have your alts". She continues saying "close," then another female speaker says "yes, cause we and we made, we gave our tenth millionth meal yesterday for God's love. Isn't that great?". The crowd applauds lightly, then the second female says to the first "You are the star of the show. There's no doubt about it". The first woman speaks, "And that and and you took on what was she? A poker player?". A male voice mentions "Any Dousche". The second female says "You still don't like her? You are still pissed at her. Yeah.". The first female states "It doesn't go away", to which the second speaker responds "no, it doesn't go away.". The first speaker says "Why what what, so what's the link?".

The clip begins with the lively speech of two women in conversation, one expressing "I don't want to give people publicity that do not deserve it." She moves on to describing her history with charity including a questionable comment about saving children from Michael Jackson, followed by a joke about a new charity for sexually deprived seniors called "Feels on wheels." Amidst the laughter that follows, she firmly states that she is "definitely into charity." The other woman prompts about Perez Hilton, leading to a discussion on how negativity attracts attention, saying that if magazines only wrote nice things, people wouldn't watch them. As more laughter erupts, she then makes a humorous comment stating that she would rather hear that others are worse off than her and that she is dating men "now that they're dying."

The clip begins with laughter, presumably from the audience. Then a woman begins to speak about dates, saying "there are no second dates." She then mentions being busy and having a new show coming out, along with being roasted on Comedy Central. A woman's voice transitions to ask how the speaker keeps it together. These remarks seem to suggest the speaker is an entertainer being interviewed. The woman's voice praises the speaker's looks.

The audio clip opens with a tense exchange between two speakers, one female voice pressuring the other to confess something, demanding "Tell me what you did." The second female voice replies tersely, "Nothing," followed by the first speaker exclaiming derisively, "You are such a bitch, nothing." Laughter is heard, presumably from the speaker, followed by the second speaker resuming with a lighthearted tone about liars and what they would do. She continues in a conversational manner, adding humor, as she says, "I'm not against it." The tone shifts slightly as she playfully criticizes the other person's appearance, referencing "tracks going up the back of your head" and joking about running a train.

The audio clip starts with the sound of audience laughter, followed by a female speaker remarking on a friend's appearance, saying, "I love it when friends look at youâ€¦ and they say, 'I'm just rested.'" She then delivers a punchline in a sarcastic tone, "Yeah, you fell asleep on the operating table", generating more laughter. The speaker continues, relating an anecdote about wiping behind her ears, and says "Nobody can make fun of you because you do it first", with a humorous tone. The audio clip concludes with a short burst of audience laughter.

The audio features two female speakers in what sounds like a conversation, possibly recorded in a public setting. The initial speaker mentions "Celebrity Apprentice" and references someone named Melissa, whose daughter is around the same age as the other speaker's daughter. The second speaker then talks about Melissa "dating someone she likes" and mentions that usually daughters bring home "things you go what is this", followed by laughter suggesting a lighthearted or humorous context.

The audio begins with a woman speaking in a somewhat comical and mocking tone, expressing that someone "should have brought me Bernie Madoff." The woman questions "Why?" while chuckling. She then explains that it should have been before Madoff was caught, when he was still "giving out some money," implying that she would have taken a portion of the money for herself, specifically mentioning the large sum of "63 billion dollars." The audio concludes with her humorous suggestion to "keep a little for ourselves."

The clip starts with a female speaker asking "what do you think about same-sex marriage?". A male speaker immediately responds in a joking tone "I'm totally against it", then goes on to explain that it's because he is tired of buying so many wedding gifts for his gay friends. He claims that they are calling him, asking to use his house and offering to bring the cheese, using his house for everything, and that he doesn't know what gifts to buy. Background laughter can be heard during his speech.

A male speaker briefly introduces a female guest. The female guest mentions that she is appearing at a hotel. A male speaker jokes about the female guest getting rich. The female guest jokes about an individual being a stand up comedian. A male speaker jokes about this briefly. The female guest expresses joy for her role model. The female speaker says the phrase, "Learn from Joan." The female guest jokes about death. The female guest jokes about being old. She then jokes about going to Vegas and watching show girls and mentions they are gorgeous, but stupid, adding that she cheers them on and questions how stupid they really are. The audio cuts to a short interlude of laughter. The female speaker is heard laughing and saying, "What do you think is so funny?" The audio transitions back to laughter. The female speaker says she has spent her life laughing, mentioning seeing a show with a wet floor sign and that the performer fell, which the speaker found funny. She concludes that despite the wet floor, men still loved the performer.

The clip begins with two women conversing, one speaking incredulously about "all those tight little bottoms," and the other agrees, asserting, "they're enhanced." One woman asks if the other is planning further plastic surgery to which the second woman responds, "right now I'm doing kegels." Laughter erupts from the audience, which continues as one of the women says, "That's how we go." She then mentions Cindy Adams, Joan, and planning a trip when they get older, envisioning a "pauper" hotel. The same woman anticipates, "what our life is going to be like."

The audio begins with speech, presumably from two female speakers. Initially, there is an exchange with a brief reference to sharing "one nurse" before transitioning into a conversational tone. The speaker expresses how much she adored Ed McMahon, describing him as everything seen on television, honorable, generous, a team player, and a good guy. A transition occurs where the speaker recounts an anecdote about Johnny Carson not talking to her and McMahon defying this by approaching and speaking with her in a restaurant. A follow-up question asks if he paid, followed by more speech. Briefly, there is a sound of muffled laughter, which leads back to the conversational tone.

The audio clip begins with upbeat, cheerful music playing. A woman's voice then comes to the forefront, excitedly stating "He's a nice nice nice." She continues talking in a friendly, promotional tone, mentioning "everybody's talking to" and that they're going to have a good time living together. She asks "How did you get so rich, Jones?" and promotes a show, "new show filming is August 6th on TV Land" urging listeners to check local listings. The music continues softly behind her voice, creating a lively, promotional atmosphere.

The audio clip starts with a female speaker excitedly announcing Elizabeth will "find out different ways that she can give birth," specifically regarding "baby number three". Her tone is enthusiastic and anticipatory. This is followed by a burst of upbeat, lively dance music. The music sounds like a live performance because we can hear enthusiastic cheers and applause from the crowd as well.
